generif.text: GPR92 is proposed as a fifth LPA receptor, LPA5, which likely has distinct physiological functions in view of its expression pattern.
FPP and NAG play a role in the sensory nervous system through activation of GPR92
Four residues involved in ligand recognition in LPA(5) were identified as follows: R2.60N mutant abolished receptor activation, whereas H4.64E, R6.62A, and R7.32A greatly reduced receptor activation.
Data show that CLL cells express LPA receptors LPA(1-5) and VEGF receptors, and the plasma levels of VEGF are elevated in CLL patients.
LPA4 and LPA5 receptors induce osteoblastic differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells
LPA5 is a bona fide LPA receptor on human mast cells responsible for the majority of LPA induced MIP-1beta release.

It was shown that lysophosphatidic acid 5 receptor transactivated the epidermal growth factor receptor and that inhibition of epidermal growth factor receptor blocked lysophosphatidic acid 5 receptor-dependent activation of NHE3.
These results suggest that LPA5 may act as a negative regulator of cellular responses in mouse fibroblast 3T3 cells, similar to the case for LPA1.

MMP-2 and MMP-9 were found in HT1080L5 cells, in comparison with control cells. These results suggest that LPA signaling via LPA5 negatively regulates the cell motile and invasive activities of human sarcoma cells.
Down-regulation of LPA receptor 5 contributes to aberrant LPA signalling in EBV-associated nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
These results suggest that the diverse roles of LPA4, LPA5 and LPA6 are involved in the activation of tumor progression in pancreatic cancer cells.
These results suggest that the cell motile activity is regulated through the induction of LPA5 by phorbol ester and anticancer drug treatments in A375cells.
It signaling may play a key role in the mechanisms underlying neuropathic pain following demyelination in the brain.
LPAR2 and LPAR5 regulate cellular functions during tumor progression in fibrosarcoma HT1080 cells.
LPA5 Is an Inhibitory Receptor That Suppresses CD8 T-Cell Cytotoxic Function via Disruption of Early TCR Signaling.

LPAR5 expression was elevated in A375cells treated with anticancer drugs. The high cell survival of highly migratory A375cells is associated with the low LPAR5 expression. The cell survival of A375cells treated with anticancer drugs was increased by LPA5 knockdown.
Downregulation of LPAR5 expression can inhibit the physiological process of PTC, and this phenomenon is related to the PI3K/AKT pathway and EMT.
Lysophosphatidic acid receptor 5 transactivation of TGFBR1 stimulates the mRNA expression of proteoglycan synthesizing genes XYLT1 and CHST3.
LPAR5 stimulates the malignant progression of non-small-cell lung carcinoma by upregulating MLLT11.
Lysophosphatidic acid mediates the pathogenesis of psoriasis by activating keratinocytes through LPAR5.
LPAR5 promotes thyroid carcinoma cell proliferation and migration by activating class IA PI3K catalytic subunit p110beta.
Control of Intestinal Epithelial Permeability by Lysophosphatidic Acid Receptor 5.

Interference with lysophosphatidic acid receptor 5 ameliorates oxidized low-density lipoprotein-induced human umbilical vein endothelial cell injury by inactivating NOD-like receptor family, pyrin domain containing 3 inflammasome signaling.
LPAR5 confers radioresistance to cancer cells associated with EMT activation via the ERK/Snail pathway.
Infiltration of LPAR5[+] macrophages in osteosarcoma tumor microenvironment predicts better outcomes.
Potential role of LPAR5 gene in prognosis and immunity of thyroid papillary carcinoma and pan-cancer.
Emerging roles of lysophosphatidic acid receptor subtype 5 (LPAR5) in inflammatory diseases and cancer.
Crosstalk between cannabinoid receptor 2 and lysophosphatidic acid receptor 5.

BP.term: positive regulation of CREB transcription factor activity

name: lysophosphatidic acid receptor 5

kegg.name: Phospholipase D signaling pathway - Homo sapiens (human)
Regulation of actin cytoskeleton - Homo sapiens (human)
Pathogenic Escherichia coli infection - Homo sapiens (human)

summary: This gene encodes a member of the rhodopsin class of G protein-coupled transmembrane receptors. This protein transmits extracellular signals from lysophosphatidic acid to cells through heterotrimeric G proteins and mediates numerous cellular processes. Many G protein receptors serve as targets for pharmaceutical drugs. Transcript variants of this gene have been described.[provided by RefSeq, Dec 2008].
